title: dplyr Basics
text:
This document introduces the dplyr workflow for cleaning, transforming, and summarizing data in R.
You will learn how to:

select columns with select()
filter rows with filter()
sort data with arrange()
create new variables with mutate()
summarize data with summarise()
group operations with group_by()
combine datasets with joins

title: dplyr Basics
text:
2.1 Install (one-time)


Show the code
# install.packages("tidyverse")

title: dplyr Basics
text:
2.2 Load packages


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

title: dplyr Basics
text:
5.1 Select a few columns


Show the code
mpg |>
  select(manufacturer, model, displ, hwy)


# A tibble: 234 × 4
   manufacturer model      displ   hwy
   <chr>        <chr>      <dbl> <int>
 1 audi         a4           1.8    29
 2 audi         a4           1.8    29
 3 audi         a4           2      31
 4 audi         a4           2      30
 5 audi         a4           2.8    26
 6 audi         a4           2.8    26
 7 audi         a4           3.1    27
 8 audi         a4 quattro   1.8    26
 9 audi         a4 quattro   1.8    25
10 audi         a4 quattro   2      28
# ℹ 224 more rows

title: dplyr Basics
text:
5.2 Select a range of columns


Show the code

  select(manufacturer:year)

10 audi         a4 quattro   2    2008

title: dplyr Basics
text:
5.3 Remove columns


Show the code

  select(-cty, -hwy)

title: dplyr Basics
text:
6.1 Filter by a condition


Show the code

  filter(class == "compact")

    cty_per_liter = cty / displ

title: dplyr Basics
dplyr Basics
text:
9.1 One summary value


Show the code
mpg |>
  summarise(mean_hwy = mean(hwy))


# A tibble: 1 × 1
  mean_hwy
     <dbl>
1     23.4

title: dplyr Basics
text:
9.2 Multiple summaries


Show the code
mpg |>
  summarise(
    mean_hwy = mean(hwy),
    sd_hwy   = sd(hwy),
    max_hwy  = max(hwy),
    min_hwy  = min(hwy)
  )


# A tibble: 1 × 4
  mean_hwy sd_hwy max_hwy min_hwy
     <dbl>  <dbl>   <int>   <int>
1     23.4   5.95      44      12


✅ Tip: Use na.rm = TRUE if your data has missing values.

title: dplyr Basics
text:
10.1 Mean highway MPG by class


Show the code
mpg |>
  group_by(class) |>
  summarise(mean_hwy = mean(hwy), .groups = "drop") |>
  arrange(desc(mean_hwy))


# A tibble: 7 × 2
  class      mean_hwy
  <chr>         <dbl>
1 compact        28.3
2 subcompact     28.1
3 midsize        27.3
4 2seater        24.8
5 minivan        22.4
6 suv            18.1
7 pickup         16.9

title: dplyr Basics
text:
10.2 Count rows by group


Show the code
mpg |>
  group_by(drv) |>
  summarise(n = n(), .groups = "drop")


# A tibble: 3 × 2
  drv       n
  <chr> <int>
1 4       103
2 f       106
3 r        25

title: dplyr Basics
text:
15.1 left_join() (most common)


Show the code
students |>
  left_join(grades, by = "id")


# A tibble: 3 × 3
     id name  score
  <dbl> <chr> <dbl>
1   101 Alex     95
2   102 Bella    NA
3   103 Chris    88

title: dplyr Basics
text:
15.2 inner_join()


Show the code
students |>
  inner_join(grades, by = "id")


# A tibble: 2 × 3
     id name  score
  <dbl> <chr> <dbl>
1   101 Alex     95
2   103 Chris    88

title: dplyr Basics
text:
15.3 anti_join() (find non-matches)


Show the code
students |>
  anti_join(grades, by = "id")


# A tibble: 1 × 2
     id name 
  <dbl> <chr>
1   102 Bella

title: Olivia Trupia
text: Olivia Trupia majors in Data Analytics at SUNY Geneseo. When not working on data analytics, Olivia enjoys spending time watching movies and listening to music in her free time.

title: Olivia Trupia
text:
Education
State University of New York at Geneseo | Geneseo, NY  B.S. in Data Analytics | Aug 2023 - May 2027

text:

title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Post With Code
text:
This is a post with executable code with no space in the folder name.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Starwars
text:
Let’s analyze the starwars data:
starwars <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/starwars.csv")

title: Starwars
text:
Variable Description for starwars data.frame
The following describes the variables in the starwars data.frame.

films List of films the character appeared in
name Name of the character
species Name of species
height Height (cm)
mass Weight (kg)
hair_color, skin_color, eye_color Hair, skin, and eye colors
birth_year Year born (BBY = Before Battle of Yavin)
sex The biological sex of the character, namely male, female, hermaphroditic, or none (as in the case for Droids).
gender The gender role or gender identity of the character as determined by their personality or the way they were programmed (as in the case for Droids).
homeworld Name of homeworld

title: Starwars
text:
Human vs. Droid

ggplot(data = 
         starwars %>% 
         filter(species %in% c("Human", "Droid"))) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = species, y = mass, 
                   fill = species),
               show.legend = FALSE)

title: Data Project
text:
“Tidy datasets are all alike, but every messy dataset is messy in its own way.” — Hadley Wickham

R is a powerful language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. It is widely used among statisticians and data analysts for data analysis and developing statistical software. Here are some basic concepts and elements of R to help you get started:



Variables in R are used to store data. You can create a variable using the assignment operator <- (option/Alt + -). For example:


Code
my_variable <- 10


This will store the value 10 in my_variable.





R has several basic data types:

Numeric: For decimal values like 2.5.
Integer: For whole numbers like 2L (the L tells R it is an integer).
Character: For text or string values, e.g., "Hello".
Logical: For boolean values (TRUE or FALSE).






Vectors are a basic data structure in R. They contain elements of the same type. You can create a vector using the c() function:


Code
my_vector <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)






Data frames are used for storing data tables in R. It is a list of vectors of equal length. For example, to create a simple data frame:


Code
df <- data.frame(
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob"), 
  Age = c(25, 30)
  )






Functions are used to carry out specific tasks in R. For example, sum() is a function that adds numbers together:


Code
sum(1, 2, 3) # Returns 6


[1] 6






R has a vast collection of packages for various statistical tasks. You can install a package using install.packages("packageName") and load it using library(packageName).


Code
# install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)






To get help on a specific function or topic, use the help() function or the shorthand ?, like ?sum on R Console.

title: Data Project
text:
Variables in R are used to store data. You can create a variable using the assignment operator <- (option/Alt + -). For example:


Code
my_variable <- 10


This will store the value 10 in my_variable.

Character: For text or string values, e.g., "Hello".
Logical: For boolean values (TRUE or FALSE).

title: Data Project
text:
R has a vast collection of packages for various statistical tasks. You can install a package using install.packages("packageName") and load it using library(packageName).


Code
# install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)

title: Data Project
text: To get help on a specific function or topic, use the help() function or the shorthand ?, like ?sum on R Console.

title: Data Project
text:
2.1 Key Concepts

Data: The raw data that you want to plot.
aes() (Aesthetic Mappings): Defines how data are mapped to color, size, shape, and other visual properties.
Geoms (Geometric Objects): The type of objects that represent data points, like points, lines, bars, etc.
Facets: For creating small multiples, splitting data into subsets and displaying the same plot for each subset.
Scales: Control how data values are translated to visual properties.
Coordinate Systems: The plane in which data is plotted, e.g., Cartesian, polar.
Themes: Control the overall appearance of the plot, like background color, grid lines, and font sizes.

title: Data Project
text:
2.2 Examples
Let’s go through some examples to illustrate how ggplot can be used to create different types of visualizations.

2.2.1 Scatter Plot
Creating a scatter plot to explore the relationship between two variables, say mpg (miles per gallon) and wt (weight of the car) from the mtcars dataset.


Code
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + 
  geom_point() +
  labs(x = "Weight of Car", y = "Miles Per Gallon",
       title = "Scatter plot of MPG vs Car Weight")









This code block creates a scatter plot where car weight is on the x-axis and miles per gallon on the y-axis. Each point represents a car.


2.2.2 Bar Chart
Creating a bar chart to show the count of cars by the number of cylinders.


Code
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = factor(cyl))) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  labs(x = "Number of Cylinders", y = "Count",
       title = "Count of Cars by Cylinders")









This plots a bar chart where each bar represents the count of cars with a certain number of cylinders.


2.2.3 Line Graph
Plotting a line graph, assuming we have a time series data.frame economics that is part of ggplot2 package.


Code
ggplot(economics, aes(x = date, y = unemploy)) + 
  geom_line() +
  labs(x = "Year", y = "Number of Unemployed Persons",
       title = "Unemployment over Time") 









This code plots the unemployment numbers over time, with time on the x-axis and the number of unemployed persons on the y-axis.


2.2.4 Faceted Plot
Creating a faceted plot to compare scatter plots of mpg vs wt across different numbers of cylinders.


Code
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = wt, y = mpg)) + 
  geom_point() +
  facet_wrap(~cyl) +
  labs(title = "MPG vs Weight by Number of Cylinders")









This splits the data into subsets based on the number of cylinders and creates a scatter plot for each subset.

title: Data Project
text:
2.3 Conclusion
ggplot2 provides a powerful and flexible system for making a wide variety of plots. By understanding the grammar of graphics upon which it is based, you can build up complex visualizations from simple components, allowing for a deep and intuitive exploration of data.

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
This document introduces the ggplot2 workflow for building clear and professional visualizations in R.
You will learn how to:

create scatterplots, line plots, and bar charts
map variables to aesthetics (aes())
control color, size, transparency, and labels
use facet_wrap() to compare groups
polish plots with themes and annotations

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
2.1 Install (one-time)


Show the code
# install.packages("tidyverse")

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
2.2 Load packages


Show the code
library(tidyverse)

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
5.1 Basic scatterplot


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
5.2 Add transparency


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5)

title: ggplot2 Basics
section: 5.3 Map color to a categorical variable
text:
5.3 Map color to a categorical variable


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, color = class)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7)

title: ggplot2 Basics
section: 5.4 Map size to a numeric variable
text:
5.4 Map size to a numeric variable


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy, size = cyl)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6)









✅ Rule of thumb:
- color = ... inside aes() means it changes by data values
- color = "blue" outside aes() means fixed color

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
6.1 Add a smooth trend


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
6.2 Linear regression line


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = displ, y = hwy)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
8.1 Count bar chart


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = class)) +
  geom_bar()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
8.2 Flip coordinates (nice for long labels)


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = class)) +
  geom_bar() +
  coord_flip()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
8.3 Bar chart with fill color


Show the code
ggplot(mpg, aes(x = class, fill = drv)) +
  geom_bar()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
9.1 Step 1: Summarize with dplyr


Show the code
mpg_mean <- mpg |>
  group_by(class) |>
  summarise(mean_hwy = mean(hwy), .groups = "drop")

mpg_mean


# A tibble: 7 × 2
  class      mean_hwy
  <chr>         <dbl>
1 2seater        24.8
2 compact        28.3
3 midsize        27.3
4 minivan        22.4
5 pickup         16.9
6 subcompact     28.1
7 suv            18.1

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
9.2 Step 2: Plot the summarized data


Show the code
ggplot(mpg_mean, aes(x = class, y = mean_hwy)) +
  geom_col()









✅ geom_bar() counts rows automatically.
✅ geom_col() uses your own y-values.

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
10.1 Basic line plot


Show the code
ggplot(sales, aes(x = month, y = revenue)) +
  geom_line()

title: ggplot2 Basics
text:
10.2 Line + points


Show the code
ggplot(sales, aes(x = month, y = revenue)) +
  geom_line() +
  geom_point()

title: Ben and Jerrys
text:
Let’s analyze the ice_cream data:
ice_cream <- read_csv("https://bcdanl.github.io/data/ben-and-jerry-cleaned.csv")

title: Ben and Jerrys
text:
Variable Description for ice_cream data.frame
The following describes the variables in the ice_cream data.frame.

flavors List of flavors
price Price of the ice cream
size Size of ice cream
id household id
size household size
used coupon if coupon was used or not
coupon per item how much the coupon was
`region`` Where it was (Central, West, South, East)
married If they are married or not
race The race of the household

title: Ben and Jerrys
text: Distribution of Icecream Price
